physDesc.p: This letter is two pages long. On the first page, the words “Poetry Monroe” are written in pencil at the top. The second page also has, typed, H.M. in the top left corner, and the date (12/23/15) in the top right corner.

div.p: Thank you very much for your nice letter. I am very glad indeed that Mrs. Freer is doing my book. I know very well what an excellent person she is for the task.

I had a letter from Flint yesterday, in which he told me that he had sent you another copy of the review of "e;Six French Poets"e; which he had enclosed to me, and had asked you, if you could not use it, to send it on to some other paper. It was a funny coincidence that Margaret Anderson had written to me that very morning, saying that she was at a loss to get anybody who could review it to her satisfaction, and could I suggest anyone to her. As I knew you had already arranged for Mrs. Freer, and that the review was doubtless written, if not printed, I wired you this morning, and enclosed Flint's review to Margaret Anderson this afternoon. I trust that my actions will meet with your approval.

I do want to get on to that Poetry supper. I don't know when I wanted to do anything so much. I have never ceased to regret that I was not at the last one, and your suggestion that I can make a speech is almost irresistible. But I do not think there is the slightest prospect that I shall be well enough to travel out to you by the 23rd. I am going to see the doctor again next week, and if there is any chance that he thinks the nose can wait a while, I will let you know; but I have been having a very bad time with it for some years, and now it seems to have culminated in a condition
closely akin to asphyxiation, and I guess the sooner it is attended to the better. It is awfully good of you to want me, and I did hope to get to Chicago in January, but now it looks to me as if March were a more likely time. However, if I can leave it open, that would at least give me the feeling that there was hope.

I have written a defence of you in answer to Aiken's article in the "e;Poetry Journal"e; in the same paper. As Aiken published his abuse there, it seems the proper place to reply to him. I trust you will like it. It is supposed to appear in the next number, but as the numbers are generally three months late, there seems no reason to suppose you will see it before Spring, or the public either for that matter, when they will have forgotten all about Aiken. But it cannot be helped.
A very Merry Christmas to you, Harriet, and the best of New Years!
